utterances: Both Peter and Carl are here with us now in Studio 3A.
Thanks for joining us.
Especially Carl, I understand we're cutting into your naptime.
It's at the middle of my naptime.
Ha.
Yeah.
So we can understand if something's--well, never mind.
If you hear me snoring, you know what happened.
Peter, news satire, Washington, D.C.; you seem to have come to the source.
Yes, exactly.
I feel like the characters in King Solomon's Mines who come through the foliage and see before them the great treasure that they've been looking for.
It's El Dorado for stupid things.
And you've come to the El Dorado of stupid things.
I have.
I've come to the very epicenter, the holy of holy.
I had to remove my shoes before walking in here to Studio 3A, because more stupid things have been said here…
You usually broadcast the show out of Chicago, though you travel a lot…
We do.
…all throughout many parts of the country.
Do you think being outside The Beltway helps you to shape your brand of news?
I think so.
I mean, to the extent that we are able to be representative of the normal human being.
Insofar as that's ever possible for myself.
And soon you're going to have one on the show.
I know!
Yes!
We're looking forward to that, once the authorities allow it.
But yeah, I mean, to a certain extent, as you know, Neal, people inside The Beltway talk a lot about things that are of interest to them; maybe more so, disproportionate.
We're just plain old simple folk in Chicago, eating Vienna sausages, rooting for the Cubs.
Well, Carl, you're the switch hitter in all of this.
Of course, you're on the program every week—but you're a serious journalist.
You do the news on MORNING EDITION every day.
Yes, but I have fun on this program.
On the weekend, on Thursday evening, when we're recorded in Chicago or elsewhere in the country--like, we'll be doing this tomorrow evening in Washington.
But it's a lot of fun.
It's a good break.
It's getting away from the seriousness of everyday news, Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday for me.
And I hop on this program, which is described as NPR without the dignity.
Yes.
One of these days Carl's going to get confused, sleep deprivation, and do the morning newscast as Anna Nicole Smith.
And the question is, will the world notice?
(Soundbite of laughter)
We want to give you all a chance to talk with this crew from WAIT, WAIT DON'T TELL ME!
E-mail is talk@npr.org.
And Amber(ph) is on the line.
Well, Amber's from Flagstaff, Arizona.
Carl, you're the person whose voice is on all those answering machines around the country.
Why don't you answer this call?
Okay.
Hello, this is Carl Kasell, NPR News.
And right now we have Amber on the phone from Arizona.
Hi, Amber.
Hi.
How are you?
Fine, thank you.
How are you doing?
How are things in Arizona?
They're beautiful today.
And it's an honor to be on the air with you guys.
Thanks for taking my call.
Sure.
Sure.
I mostly have a question about the writers on WAIT, WAIT DON'T TELL ME!, mostly because I wanted to know how much Peter, you're involved, and where you guys get your ideas.
Because it is pretty clever.
We listen to it every week, so…
I'm glad.

Well, the show is written sort of collaboratively by our staff, which is myself, and if I can run through the list, Rod Abid, Amanda Gibson, Emily Ecton, and Mike Danforth, with our executive producer, Doug Berman.
And we do it all together.
We spend a lot of time in front of the computers trying to find interesting stuff in the news to talk about, and then sometime around Wednesday we just give it up and just make it all up.
Just start pulling stuff out of our word processor, and end up with--no, actually, the show is written by all of us.
I am sort of the de facto head writer because I have to say most of it.

But then what's interesting is what happens is we tape the show in front of a live audience, and basically a lot of the stuff that we write goes out the window in favor of stuff our panelist thinks up.

On the campaign trail, Trump has been blaming the economic downturn of the early '90s for his financial problems, but NPR's Joel Rose reports that former employees and business associates say Trump was also to blame.
How do you lose more than $900 million?
We asked someone who used to work for Donald Trump.
I think a good part of it was mistakes.
Barbara Res is a former executive vice president at the Trump Organization.
She managed construction at Trump Tower.
Res says the mistake started in the 1980s when Trump paid $365 million for a failing airline and 400 million for the Plaza Hotel.
He overpaid from all that stuff, so those were not wise decisions.
Those were mistakes on his part.
Those mistakes alone don't quite account for the $900 million loss that's reported on Trump's state tax returns in 1995.
We don't know exactly where that figure comes from because only a few pages were leaked.
A loss that big could have allowed Trump to avoid paying federal income tax for years.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
As a businessperson, I've legally used the tax laws to benefit - really I mean it's to my benefit - and the benefit of my company, my investors, my employees, my family.
At a rally yesterday in Colorado, Trump did not dispute the broad strokes of the story, but he blamed the recession of the early 1990s for his financial problems.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
I was able to use the tax laws of our country and my skills as a businessperson to dig out of this real estate depression when few others were able to do that.
But some say Trump brought those massive losses on himself by borrowing too much.
All the assets that he bought - the shuttle, his real estate - he believed he could make a lot of money on them.
He was wrong.
His judgment was wrong.
Alan Pomerantz is a lawyer who represented dozens of banks in negotiations with Trump.
At one point in the early '90s, Trump owed $3.4 billion.
He was personally on the hook for more than $800 million of that money.
Pomerantz says investors lost big while Trump claimed the tax benefits for himself.
The only reason he gets to a $900 million loss is 'cause he lost the money by doing that kind of very risky business, by being a gambler, if you will.
He took an inappropriate risk for other people's money.
Trump's biggest gamble, the one that may have hurt him the most, was the Trump Taj Mahal casino in Atlantic City.
Trump paid more than $600 million for the unfinished casino.
The eighth wonder of the world, as it was billed, opened in 1990 and filed for bankruptcy the next year.
Steven Perskie was the head of the New Jersey Casino Control Commission at the time.
We certainly knew that the big financial picture for Trump was terrible as opposed to what he was marketing to the rest of the world.
The Casino Commission could have revoked Trump's gaming license, but it didn't.
Trump had two other casinos in Atlantic City, and the commission was trying to protect the city's main industry.
Alan Pomerantz says the bankers he represented made a similar calculation when they allowed Trump to sell off the assets he could no longer afford.
What we did as a bank group is we said, you know, why should we be self-destructive and put the guy into bankruptcy?
We'll get less out of him than if we send him out here and make him walk around as if he is still successful and alive and sell all the stuff for us.
